Profile.value: Pacific Office Fiji, with own DRR

developmentContext.title: Development Context
developmentContext.content:
Solomon Islands, also well-known as the Hapi Isles, is an archipelago of 992 islands with over 720 000 people who speak more than 70 languages, which testifies to the islands’ tremendous cultural diversity.

Solomon Islands is a youthful nation: seven out of ten Solomon Islanders are below the age of 34. This huge demographic segment has not been targeted enough by development assistance and peacebuilding work and suffers from high unemployment. The lack of stable employment opportunities affect income generation and poverty reduction efforts and makes youth extremely vulnerable to crime and violence. The 2018 Solomon Islands State of Youth Report reveals youth challenges: they feel disadvantaged, disempowered and have low self-esteem. Youth are marginalized from social, economic and political activities in their communities.

Solomon Islands’ economy is based on agriculture, forestry and fisheries, which together contribute about 40% of GDP and provide employment for the majority of the population.

successesInDevelopment.title: Successes in Development
successesInDevelopment.content: Since 1990 Solomon Islands’ life expectancy at birth, mean years of schooling, and expected years of schooling have increased, as well as the country’s GNI per capita increased by about 20.2 per cent, to USD 2,493 in 2020. In addition, The proportion of the population living below the extreme poverty line declined from 46.0 % in 2005 to 25.0% in 2013 while access to electricity has increased from 15.7 % in 1999 to 62.9% in 2017. The 2014 Solomon Islands National Energy Policy has provided an enabling platform that has informed decision makers on policy directions and strategies for improving the effectiveness of the Solomon Island energy sector through increased access to reliable, affordable and clean sources of electricity.

challengesInDevelopment.title: Challenges in Development
challengesInDevelopment.content:
Since independence Solomon Islands has struggled to maximize its development potential but still remains a Least Developed Country (LDC). There has been no rapid development similar to island states such as Singapore or Macau but rather the country has progressed in small, measured steps. Its HDI was 135 out of 177 in 2009 a change from 121 out of 174 in 2000. Solomon Islands is presently ranked 151st for 2020 in UNDP’s 2020 Human Development Report, which put the country in the Low Human Development category.

The National Development Strategy (NDS) and Voluntary National Review (VNR) highlight economic instability, governance, and law rule among Comoros’ key challenges. Another major challenge is the high cost and administrative difficulty of delivering services to a largely subsistence population dispersed across many islands with minimal infrastructure and expensive transport links. The majority of Solomon Islanders (approx. 85%) live in remote rural areas. Because of the geographic situation, they depend not only on energy supply and connectivity but also on climate change and the increasing frequency of natural disasters.

Solomon Islands’ women have had full suffrage since 1974 however, the country has only ever had three women Parliamentarians. The political marginalization of women contributes to women's undervaluing and the high rate of sexual and gender-based violence. Both are factors in the alienation of half population, weakening the social fabric essential for peace and stability. Young women face the double disadvantage of both social expectations of their age and their gender. Women have played an important role as advocates for peace, but their influence on decision-making processes limits that role.
